Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: The rain had been relentless all morning, and as I stood in the half-finished lobby, my phone buzzed with another update from the city: flash-flood warning, evacuate low-lying areas. As the architect, I was supposed to keep the project moving, coordinate with the contractors, and make sure the schedule didn’t slip. The foreman was already at my side, asking if we should keep the crew working or call it for the day. But as a citizen, I knew the city expected me to act responsibly—follow emergency guidance, help others, and not put anyone at risk. The alarms blared, echoing off the concrete, and I could see water pooling at the curb outside. My mind raced: if I sent everyone home, we’d lose precious time and money. If I kept them here, I’d be ignoring the warnings, risking their safety, and failing my duty to the community. My heart pounded as I looked from the anxious faces of the workers to the rising water outside, torn between my responsibility to the project and my responsibility to the people around me.
